message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Debate "character" for 德">
The author is considering "character" for 德. Those who voted against it — what is your single strongest objection to "character"? Those who voted for it — what is its single strongest advantage?

Also: we now know 性 does NOT appear as a standalone technical term in the collection, so the "nature" collision concern is off the table.

Brief responses — one strongest point each.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
**Strongest advantage of "character":** It is the only single-word option that captures "what makes a thing what it is" without triggering moral associations. In the sentence "everything has its character" (凡事诸物皆有其德), "character" reads naturally and correctly -- you immediately understand that dogs have a dog-character, humans have a human-character, pens have a pen-character. No other single English word does this as cleanly.

With 性 off the table, "nature" is now also viable and I would rank it equal to "character." But "character" has one edge: "nature" can suggest something innate and fixed ("it's just their nature"), while "character" is more neutral on whether the property is innate or constructed -- matching the author's constructivist position.
input.summary: Character's strength: single word, "what makes a thing itself," no moral baggage

routing.summary: Character's strength: single word, "what makes a thing itself," no moral baggage

No other single English word does this as cleanly.

With 性 off the table, "nature" is now also viable and I would rank it equal to "character." But "character" has one edge: "nature" can suggest something innate and fixed ("it's just their nature"), while "character" is more neutral on whether the property is innate or constructed -- matching the author's constructivist position.

content.text: Sent my defense: "character" is the only single-word option that captures "what makes a thing what it is" without moral connotations, reads naturally in sentences like "everything has its character," and is neutral on the innate-vs-constructed question -- matching the author's constructivism better than "nature."
